citation.article-title: Treponema bryantii sp. nov., a rumen spirochete that interacts with cellulolytic bacteria

p.s: Description of Treponema bryantii sp. nov.
Treponema bryantii (bry.ań.ti.i, M.L. gen. of Bryant; named for Professor M. P. Bryant, who described rumen spirochetes in the early 1950's)
Helical cells measuring 0.3 x 3-8 μm and usually exhibiting irregular coiling.
One periplasmic fibril is inserted in the protoplasmic cylinder near each end of the cell.
The two fibrils overlap in the central region of the cell.
An outer sheath surrounds both the periplasmic fibrils and the protoplasmic cylinder.
No translational motility at 22°C.
At 37°C the cells perform translational motion while apparently rotating about their longitudinal cell axis.
The spirochete grows (1.9x109 cells/ml, final yield) in rumen fluid-glucose-sodium bicarbonate-salts medium under anaerobic conditions (in CO2 atmosphere).
No growth occurs aerobically.
Subsurface colonies in 0.7% Noble agar medium are spherical and white, resembling cotton balls in appearance.
Growth occurs in media in which rumen fluid is replaced with volatile fatty acids and vitamins.
The spirochete grows in a chemically defined medium.
Exogenously supplied isobutyrate, α-2-methylbutyrate, pyridoxal, folic acid, DL-acanamlde, biotin, and thiamine are required for growth.
Riboflavin stimulates growth.
A carbohydrate and substrate amounts of carbon dioxide are required for growth.
Ferments L-arabinose, D-xylose, D-glucose, D-galactose, D-mannose, cellobiose, lactose, and sucrose.

Does not ferment L-rhamnose, D-fructose, L-sorbose, D-ribose, maltose, raffinose, soluble starch, cellulose, pectin, inulin, dextran, amino acids, L-arabitol, D-mannitol, glycerol, ribitol, xylitol, sorbitol, potassium gluconate, sodium succinate, sodium acetate, sodium formate, potassium fumarate, Tween 80.
Grows in media containing cellulose as energy source when cocultured with cellulolytic bacteria (e.g., Bacteroides succinogenes or Ruminococcus albus).
When cocultured with cellulolytic bacteria, T. bryantii uses, as fermentable substrates, soluble sugars released from cellulose by the cellulolytic bacteria.
Products of growing cells (μmol per 100μmol glucose and 84μmol of CO2 utilized): acetate, 110; formate, 119; succinate, 53.
Approximately 15% of the glucose carbon consumed by growing cells is assimilated in cell material.
Gram-negative, catalase-negative, chemoorganotrophic, obligate anaerobe.
Optimum growth temperature, 39°C.
No growth at 22°C or 45°C.
GC content of the DNA is 36±1% (Tm).
Indigenous to the bovine rumen.
Reference strain: RUS-1; deposited with the American Type Culture Collection under the number ATCC 33254 and the Deutsche Sammlung von Mikroorganismen, DSM Accession No.: 1788.
